abstract_summ: However, severe abdominal pain associated with COVID-19 warranting surgical evaluation has been rarely described; recognizing such presentations and differentiating them from a surgical abdomen is critical to effectively and safely manage COVID-19 patients.There is currently a lack of published case reports describing COVID-19 patients with the sole symptoms of anosmia and ageusia in the United States of America.This case report describes the clinical characteristics of a 50-year-old woman that developed SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia and was admitted at the COVID-19 dedicated unit where she developed neurological symptoms 10 days after admission.Special attention should be given to patients with non-classic COVID-19 symptoms in order to reduce transmission and protect health providers.Anosmia associated or not with dysgeusia seems to be a frequent symptom in cases of infection with SARS-CoV-2 responsible for COVID-19.
title_summ: Case report: COVID-19 Masquerading as an Acute Surgical Abdomen.[Anosmia and COVID-19].Anosmia and Dysgeusia in the Absence of Other Respiratory Diseases: Should COVID-19 Infection Be Considered?Miller Fisher syndrome diagnosis and treatment in a patient with SARS-CoV-2Anosmia and Ageusia as the Only Indicators of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)Acute abdomen -like-presentation associated with SARS-CoV-2 infectionSevere SARS-CoV-2 Infection in Children With Suspected Acute Abdomen: A Case Series From a Tertiary Hospital in Spain.
title_abstract_phrases: There is currently a lack of published case reports describing COVID-19 patients with the sole symptoms of anosmia and ageusia in the United States of America.However, severe abdominal pain associated with COVID-19 warranting surgical evaluation has been rarely described; recognizing such presentations and differentiating them from a surgical abdomen is critical to effectively and safely manage COVID-19 patients.Miller Fisher syndrome diagnosis and treatment in a patient with SARS-CoV-2This case report describes the clinical characteristics of a 50-year-old woman that developed SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia and was admitted at the COVID-19 dedicated unit where she developed neurological symptoms 10 days after admission.We discuss the management course, highlight the importance of abdominal symptoms in the setting of COVID-19, and discuss the implications of this association for medical practice amid the current pandemic in both resource-rich and resource-limited settings.[Anosmia and COVID-19].Anosmia associated or not with dysgeusia seems to be a frequent symptom in cases of infection with SARS-CoV-2 responsible for COVID-19.Special attention should be given to patients with non-classic COVID-19 symptoms in order to reduce transmission and protect health providers.
